 Step 1 Baseline dataset, including the following variables : 
  • Patient ID
  • Index date
  • Study end date
  • Date of birth• Sex• SES closet to the index date • Baseline comorbidity from one-year prior to the index date: • Presence of any of the eight conditions listed in Appendix II Table 4 (i.e. total of 8 variables) 
  • Total comorbidity count
 


Step 2 Drug exposure by individual DMD and non-exposure period Create a dataset containing the following variables:
  • Patient ID
  • Start_Interval: Start date of each DMD exposure/ non-exposure period. The first Start_Interval date for each patient is the index date
  • Stop_Interval: End date of each DMD exposure/ non-exposure period. The last Stop_Interval date for each patient is the study end date. 
  • DMD_No_Ind: Exposure by individual DMD within each period (see Appendix II Table 3) or No exposure. For drug exposure calculations:
  • General rule: use the ‘days supply’ recorded in the prescription/dispensing database to calculate the time exposed to drug.
  • If multiple dispensations (i.e. same DINs or different DINs but same DMD) on the same day, the ‘days supply’ for each dispensation will be added up.  Exceptions: alemtuzumab & ocrelizumab.
  • Assume individuals cannot accrue DMD, nor can they be on >1 DMD at the same time. i.e., once a subsequent DMD prescription is filled (e.g., on DD/MM/YYYY), then assume the previous DMD was stopped (on DD/MM/YYYY minus one day).
  • Gap <90 days between the dispensations for the same DMD (note: all the beta-interferon products are considered as one DMD) will be considered as being exposed continuously to the same DMD.• Discontinuation is defined as no further dispensations for the same individual DMD lasting ≥ 90 days after the end of days supply.
  • This discontinuation date will be the last DMD prescription filled date + days of drug supplied + 30-day grace period.
 

Step 3 New comorbidities for the creation of time periods (a) Create a dataset containing new comorbidities developed between the index date and study end date. The dataset containing the following variables:
  • Patient ID
  • Comorbidity start date 
  • Individual comorbidity status (i.e. total of 8 variables) 
  • New comorbidities dates (see remarks below: +1 day )
Comorbidity start date is the date of the first ICD code for any specific comorbidity listed Appendix II Table 4.For all the new comorbidity dates: please add ONE DAY (i.e. first ICD code for diabetes was captured on 1-Jan-2014 + 1 day = 2-Jan-2014).  Keep this ‘new comorbidities’ dataset to be used in Step 5.(b) Combine new comorbidity dates and DMD exposure period/non-exposure start dates into one column:• Using the file prepared in Step 2 : Keep the variables ‘Start_Interval’ (start date for each exposure and non-exposure period), ‘DMD_No_Ind’(the exposure status) and Patient ID; Drop the variable Stop_Interval for each exposure and non-exposure period as new Stop_Interval for each period will be generated in Step 5 below. Create a separate file using the ‘new comorbidities’ dataset.
Keep the variables Patient ID and ‘New comorbidities dates’: rename the variable name ‘New comorbidity dates’ to ‘Start_Interval’. Combine all the new comorbidity dates with the DMD exposure period/non-exposure dates into one column. Sort the data and remove any duplicate dates for the variable ‘Start_Interval’ (i.e. keep only one row of date if the dates of a new comorbidity and the start date of exposure or non-exposure occurred on the same date).
